dialogue.raw_text: : 94   EXT. OLD TOBACCO WAREHOUSE - DAY                             94 A temporary sign is posted on the door and a painter is filling in the name -- "HOME IMPROVEMENT COMMISSION."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 97   INT. HOUSE - NIGHT                                           97 BB and Moe are selling to MR. and MRS. SHUBNER, a young couple. The TELEVISION is ON in the background.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 98   INT. HOSPITAL CORRIDOR                                       98 Moe is being wheeled on a gurney by a couple of nursing attendants. BB walks alongside.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (still trying to get up; wiping his face)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ... I've got nothing for all this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lot of good times, Moe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A lot of good times, but I can't live off the good times. (beat) You know, my brother-in-law has offered me a job at Hess Shoes. I think maybe I should do it. You get there in the morning, you come home at night... you get health benefits... I get to be assistant manager.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's it, Moe? You're gonna spend the day measuring people's feet? 'You're an "E" fit... you're a "D" wide... you got a high arch... I'll show you something in an alligator... something with a wing tip...' How can you talk about that all day long? (beat) Moe, you're the best tin man there ever was. Nobody's a better closer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's over, BB... it's over. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 121   CONTINUED:   (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks at Moe for a long beat.   He's obviously greatly affected by this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, May's happy about this Hess Shoe thing, heh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To say the least.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sam is driving and Tilley is in the passenger seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, when I saw 'Bonanza' the other day, something occurred to me. There's those three guys living on the Ponderosa and you never hear them say anything about wanting to get laid. You never hear Hoss turn to Little Joe and say 'I had such a hard-on when I woke up this morning.' You know ... they never talk about broads ... nothing. Ya never hear Little Joe say 'Hey, Hoss, I went into Virginia City and saw a girl with the greatest ass I ever saw in my life.' Ya just see 'em walking around the Ponderosa saying, 'Yes, Pa,' and 'Where's Little Joe?' Nothing about broads. I don't think I'm being too picky... at least once if they talked about getting horny. I don't care if you're living on the Ponderosa or right here in Baltimore, guys talk about getting laid. (beat) I'm beginning to think that show doesn't have too much realism. What do you think, Tilley?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sam, I can't concentrate on 'Bonanza' shit... (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 122   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got too much on my brain, what with that asshole and the Home Improvement Commission, I don't want to have to worry about whether Little Joe got laid last night. (beat) Let's go and eat something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, we'll go and have some lunch at the smorgasbord.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 123   INT. THOR'S SMORGASBORD RESTAURANT - DAY                      123 Tilley and Sam are in line at the buffet. Sam fills up his tray and moves off to the cashier. Tilley hangs behind staring at all the food. He looks up to the ceiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God, if you're responsible for all the stuff down here, maybe you got a moment's attention for me. (beat) Between the I.R.S., this Home Improvement Commission and Mr. Marengay, I got it up to here with this bullshit. To be frank with you, I'm in the toilet here. If you can see your way... A WOMAN with a tray starts to approach Tilley.     Tilley turns to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen, I'm praying here... go around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wanted to get some of the salad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's out of order... go around. He signals for her to walk around him.   The Woman looks at him and moves down the line. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 123   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do what you can, all right?    I appreciate it. Amen. Tilley helps himself to some salad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 124   INT. SUPERIOR ALUMINUM SIDING OFFICE - DAY                   124 The usual office activity.   BB is at a desk.   He picks up the phone and dials.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nora Tilley, please. We hear a WOMAN'S VOICE on the other end of the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What department is she with?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's with Social Security.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which department is Social Security?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I dunno... she's there somewhere ... yeah, on the third floor... she's got a desk towards the back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just a moment... checking. ANOTHER ANGLE In the b.g. Stanley has gone over to a filing cabinet and is starting to look through the files. Cheese wanders over to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stanley, can I help you look for something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I'm just making myself busy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I wouldn't do that. Bagel don't like nobody looking at the files. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 124   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on phone. He's still holding for Nora.    We hear a RING on the other end of the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Tilley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nora, this is BB. The PHONE goes DEAD.   BB reluctantly puts the receiver down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 125   INT. TOBACCO WAREHOUSE - DAY                                 125 The Home Improvement Commission is in session. Tilley and Sam sit at the defense table. Masters presides over the commission table where four or five other commis- sioners sit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Didn't you approach Mr. Boloshevski August 18, 1961, while he was cutting his front lawn and tell him that his house had been selected, as one of only 16 homes in the state of Maryland, for a free aluminum siding job?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the name again?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boloshevski.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doesn't ring a bell. (to Sam) Sam, does it ring a bell to you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It doesn't ring a bell to me either, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Didn't you suggest that for a nominal labor charge, he would receive over five thousand dollars' worth of aluminum siding? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 125   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's an awful lot for nothing. Doesn't sound like good business to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Boloshevski was ultimately charged twenty-four hundred dollars for labor, which according to our figures is about the average cost of an aluminum siding job.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't get the point of this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twenty-four hundred dollars that you charged for labor, is the same as if Mr. Boloshevski had purchased the aluminum siding and had the labor done.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe I'm missing the point here, but if he paid twenty-four hundred, which is the cost of the job, I can't see anything wrong with that. I don't know the guy, but I don't quite get the problem.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What we're getting at here... what we're trying to stress, is that the job was sold under false terms. The man didn't win any award... he was not getting aluminum siding at a special price. A clear case of deception was involved here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's he talking about? The man got the job for twenty-four hundred dollars, and that's what it costs in aluminum siding. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 125   CONTINUED:   (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Um... I don't know... we have no recollection of this particular job, but I don't know if this is deception. Look, if you work in a clothing store, some guy tries on a suit, it looks like shit, but you tell him it looks wonderful. The guy's standing there looking like a sack of shit, the salesman says what a great suit and the man buys it. That's deception as far as I can see, but I don't understand the deceptiveness that you say we're responsible for... if I make myself clear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd go along with that as well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What we're trying to establish are the principles that have been laid down as part of the Home Improvement code of ethics... that you cannot mislead someone intentionally, and I think that's the principle that applies to this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did somebody put a gun to this guy's head and make him spend twenty-four hundred dollars? I don't get the point here. I don't know the specifics of this case, not being privy to all the information, but all I can say is this guy got a fair price for a fair job. Another commissioner, BUD DELANEY, takes the microphone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know Mr. and Mrs. Rayburn of 156 Aberdeen Avenue, Essex? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 125   CONTINUED:   (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think you'd have to familiarize me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The couple purchased twenty-eight hundred dollars' worth of aluminum siding and the two of you were the salesmen on record. They say, and I quote here, 'that they would have received one hundred and fifty dollars per home for every person in the neighborhood who saw their house and decided to buy aluminum siding.' (looking up from paper) Is that true?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It sounds right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you aware that, according to the Home Improvement code, you are not allowed to exceed a twenty dollar limit in incentives?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We wanted to be a little more generous, that's all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The couple said that they never did receive any money from any other jobs, as you had promised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We didn't get any leads from them. Their house was not the showplace that we thought it would be. It didn't generate the activity that we had hoped. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 125   CONTINUED:   (4)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But should a referral turn up in the community, we'd be more than happy to give them twenty dollars instead of the hundred and fifty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse us for one moment. He then leans over to Delaney, and they start to confer. Tilley and Sam watch, wondering what's going on. Masters leans in the other direction, holding his hand over the microphone, and he talks to the other commissioners. They nod in approval, then Masters leans back into the microphone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you very much, gentlemen. Should there be a reason in the future to call you back, we would like to reserve that right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Glad we could be of some service. Tilley and Sam get up from the table and walk out of the building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 126   EXT. TOBACCO WAREHOUSE - DAY                                126 Tilley and Sam are walking toward Tilley's car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We beat 'em, Sam... we beat 'em! What a piece of cake! No problem! They ain't got nothing on us... clean as a whistle... we're clean as a whistle!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need a drink. I hate inquisitions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 122. 127   EXT. SOCIAL SECURITY OFFICE - NIGHT                           127 Heavy RAIN is falling. Nora, with an umbrella, walks quickly across the parking lot. Suddenly BB slips under the umbrella with her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want to see you anymore. She pulls away from BB and continues walking.      BB walks behind her, getting soaked in the rain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I gotta talk to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want to listen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give me a chance to explain.    You owe me that much. Nora still walking toward her car in the downpour.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't owe you anything. BB lets her walk away.   After a beat, he yells out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was a lousy thing to do, okay? It was a lousy thing to use you to get back at your husband... but the fact is that I never would have met you otherwise. Nora stops and turns to look at BB.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was lousy... it was a disgusting, terrible thing... but a lot of good came out of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What kind of a person would come up with such a devious thing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not always a nice guy, I admit that. I got a lot of training in deceit... it's an occupational hazard. They stand looking at one another in the rain. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 127   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like to know what it is about me that I have to fall for tin men. What kind of character flaw do I have?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't want to have to come here. I wish that I didn't have to ever see you again. I've gone this far in my life without having to have this kind of thing happen to me. I was going through life, sailing along, pretty good... doing okay, and I tried to get even with some crazy guy... and I'm here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The wet becomes you. Gets rid of some of the slickness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't like the idea that I'm not in control of this, but if this stuff's got to happen, I guess I've got no choice. I wanna... ya know... (he gets angry) ... I wanna be with ya! Okay, I said that... I said it, okay?! I wanna be with ya! It pisses the hell out of me, and I'm gonna tell you that to your face, but I want to be with you because... I miss you and I'd like to live with you... I'd like to marry you... and that's that! Nora eyes him carefully. The rain falls on her umbrella and the rain beats on BB's head. After a long moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was hoping for something a little more romantic... but, okay. A slight smile comes to BB's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 124. 128   INT. PIMLICO HOTEL - BAR/RESTAURANT - NIGHT             128 Tilley and Sam are sitting at the bar  nursing a couple of drinks. In the b.g., the pianist   is playing "Last Night When We Were Young," and a few  people are sitting around the piano joining in with the  song.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ya know, Tilley, we been working together for over a year.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, must be about that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been thinking that sometimes a different combination makes for better luck. Ya know what I mean? I mean, maybe the two of us ain't the right combination.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm just getting used to ya, Sam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's face it, we're not exactly setting the world on fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a slump... it's a slump, Sam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe it's a slump, but like baseball, some time they have to change the lineup to get the team going again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not serious about this, are you, Sam?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're serious? You wanna get another partner? You don't think I'm gonna pull out of this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know you're gonna... I know you're gonna.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 128   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, we beat the   Commission today ... you know, we   got a little bit of a victory.  We   split right now and maybe we can   add to that... you know what I'm   saying?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know... I know. Change in the lineup. Okay, maybe it'll help... maybe it'll help. (he drinks his whiskey) You got any ideas for a new partner?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I had a    conversation with Solly Shavitz,    so... maybe I'll go with him. (beat) Mouse is gonna   need a new partner because Dennis   is going into used cars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mouse! Mouse! He gets on my nerves... He eats too much. (beat; he holds up his whiskey glass) Here's to some pretty good times, huh? Sam smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 129   INT. CORRAL CLUB - NIGHT                                  129 Looney, looking tanned, sits with Stanley at the bar. BB and Nora are dancing in the b.g.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't get it... the broad smashes into his car and he takes her dancing. Some kind of dating ritual that I'm not familiar with.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: BB's a pretty good tin man, huh? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 129   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pretty good? Whew! Man's what legends are made of. Started selling pots and pans door to door at sixteen. Nothing he can't sell. ANGLE ON BB AND NORA The song ends and BB walks Nora back to the table they were sitting at.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're gonna come back and stay the night?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I dunno... all my things are back at Nellie's -- the other side of town. (beat) I know what I could do, I'll go back to the house... there's still a few things I left behind ... at least I can get a change of clothes. They both sit down.    BB looks at Nora.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm glad this is working out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You really happy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't really show a great deal of exuberance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honey, for me... I'm a parade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 130   EXT. STREET - TILLEY'S HOUSE - TIGHT SHOT OF HAND -           130 NIGHT Rattling a special padlock. PULL BACK to reveal Tilley at his front door, trying to get in. (CONTINUED) 127. 130   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: S to see Nora's car pulling up in front of the house. Nora turns off the car lights and exits the car. She starts up the front walk and stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The I.R.S... they need my furniture. They got some living room somewhere in this country that needs to be furnished.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're taking the furniture?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The furniture, the whole house. They locked it up... they confiscated it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you expect? You expect to get some preferential treatment ... you're some special case? You've got to pay your taxes just like everybody else has to pay their taxes! Tilley shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How many arguments did we used to have about filing your taxes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We had a lot of arguments. Nora starts toward him.     Tilley sits on the steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a responsibility that you've got to have. It's a long way from high school, Tilley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I  was doing pretty good there for a  while... doing pretty good. Had my  house, had a wife, a Cadillac... I  still got my Cadillac. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 130   CONTINUED:   (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are you gonna sleep?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll stay at Sam's for a couple of days until I get set up. (beat) What're you doing here, anyway?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's just a couple of things you didn't throw out of the house ... a couple of things I didn't find in the drawer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know... I did a pretty good house cleaning number on you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen, about the divorce. Do you want to file, or should I file?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got to be frank with you, this guy is nuts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He told me all about it... all about how you threw eggs at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He told you it was about eggs? The guy tried to break into my house. He tried to steal things from me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was trying to find me.    We had an argument.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think you'd be making a big mistake if you married him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not for you to make decisions for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think maybe I should, because I think you're being misled... I think you're confused. I think... (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 130   CONTINUED:   (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know what I'm doing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nora, listen to me. I know about guys...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I appreciate your concern, but it's not for you...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But this guy is as bad a choice as you could make. Bad choice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a good one to give advice... you're sitting on the steps, locked out of your house because you can't pay your taxes, and you're going to give me advice on life?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not giving you a divorce, and that's it. I'm looking out for your welfare. No divorce. Nora looks at him, starts to say something, then stands up and walks down the steps of the house toward her car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's for your own benefit, and you'll thank me for it. Nora turns toward Tilley and suddenly snaps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My benefit! You don't give a damn about me! You don't give a damn who I marry. The reason you don't want me to marry is because he's the one taking your wife, and you've got your own problems with him. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 130   CONTINUED:   (4)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't care about me... it's the same bullshit you're doing. That's what it always is with you, Tilley. It's always you! The I.R.S. took your house... your furniture! You don't say anything about my things in the house. I've got things in the house I worked damn hard for, and things that belonged to my family... the headboard that was given to me by Aunt Josephine, it's got to be at least a hundred years old... and the hand-embroidered footstool...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What footstool?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The hand-embroidered footstool over by the TV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't remember seeing that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's been there forever... it was my granny's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's been there forever?   I've never seen it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've never seen it!? You've never seen it!? You put your feet on it to watch TV... the hand-embroidered footstool.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know what you're talking about. I never put my feet up to watch TV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the way you are, Tilley, it doesn't mean anything to you. You don't care if they take it all away. It's all you, Tilley! That's the way it's always been. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 130   CONTINUED:   (5)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stands there for a moment, then turns back to her car, gets in, slams the door and drives off. Tilley stands on the front steps with a puzzled look on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hand-embroidered footstool? He walks over to his car, gets in and STARTS the ENGINE... shaking his head in disbelief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 131   EXT. SUPERIOR ALUMINUM BUILDING - NIGHT                     131 BB drives up to the building in his Cadillac, the pas- senger door opens and Stanley gets out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks for the lift back, BB. See ya around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, Stanley. Stanley closes the car door and BB drives off. Stanley watches BB's car turn the bend, and then he goes toward the office door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 132   INT. SUPERIOR ALUMINUM OFFICE - NIGHT                       132 Stanley is standing at the filing cabinet going through files. He takes some files and puts them to one side. Then, satisfied that he's got everything he needs, he picks up the files and turns to leave. BB is standing at the door watching him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know something, Stanley, I can always smell a guy who's not made of tin. He walks over to Stanley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's against the law to steal files. I could call and have you arrested and sent to jail, right now. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 132   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll put everything back, nobody's the wiser.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You work for the Commission, is that it? Stan nods "yes."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doesn't the Commission have enough information? They got to send out guys like you to spy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, we just started out, and if we had some really good hard facts of some infractions, it would give us a lot of credibility in the community. BB walks closer to Stanley, looks at him for a second, grabs him by his tie and pushes him backwards. Stanley crashes into the filing cabinet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what your big problem is, Stanley? You're lazy. If you want to find out stuff, then you dig... you get on the phone... you canvas... 'We're from the Home Improvement Commission...' Go find your leads... that's what we do all the time. You're just lazy, Stanley. If we're doing something wrong, you should collect all your evidence. Instead, you snoop around... steal files. What is this? Undercover time? You think you're breaking up some big drug ring? Is this the Mafia you've infiltrated? All you've got here is a bunch of guys selling tin for Christ sake! (beat) You want some files? He walks over to the filing cabinet, flips through some files and pulls out three files. Stanley has gotten up from the floor. BB throws the files down on the desk. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 132   CONTINUED:   (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here... here's some jobs I did. Leave Moe out of this... he quit the business. Stanley gathers up the files from the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go on, get out of here. Stanley starts for the door, and turns back.
direction.name: direction
